tn.text: In this chapter, Nebuchadnezzar tells what God did to him. In verses 1-18, Nebuchadnezzar describes in the first person his vision from God. Verses 19-33 switch to the third person to describe the punishment of Nebuchadnezzar. Verses 34-37 change back to first person as Nebuchadnezzar describes his response to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This phrase is referring to the king's messenger as the king himself. AT: "Nebuchadnezzar sent his messengers with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who speak different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Kings would often exaggerate how wide their kingdom was. Nebuchadnezzar did rule over most of the known world at the time this book was written. AT: "who lived in the kingdom of Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is a common greeting.

tn.ref: His kingdom is ... generation to generation
tn.text: Both of these phrases have the same meaning and are repeated to emphasize how God's reign is forever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
